head.title: Monody. Malvina for Oscar.1, 1 First published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 22, 1796), p. 2. Oscar and Malvina (1791), a popular ballet-melodrama loosely adapted from MacPherson’s Ossian by William Reeve, had been successfully staged at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, London in 1792. It was performed in the Dumfries Theatre in November 1793, as described in Burns's poem "Esopus to Maria" (Kinsley II: 769-771). When Turnbull and a troop of Dumfries actors performed the play in Whitehaven in March 1794, the Earl of Lonsdale had them arrested for vagrancy, as also described in the same Burns poem. Later it was regularly acted by the Charleston theatre company; Turnbull appeared in it as Fingal in his first Charleston season, and it was still being staged there in 1807 (Charleston Courier, Charleston, SC, April 3, 1807). 22 [GT's note: See the Poems of Ossian.]

lg.l: Sing, O sing the song of woe,
Strive not to assuwage my grief;
Bid the tears of sorrow flow,
Tears alone can bring relief.

In its fairest hues array’d,
Breathless, stretch’d upon the clay,

To gloomy Carbiari’s lofty hall,

Raging like fierce Lora’s flood,55 Of the river Lora, Macpherson comments “Lora was a small and rapid stream in the neighbourhood of Selma. There is no vestige of this name now remaining;….one of the small rivers on the north-west coast was called Lora some centuries ago.” See The Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh, 1812), p. 255.
Red with rising vengeance dire,
Quench’d his wrath in Oscar’s blood.
Fierce the strife when wintry waves,
White with icy fragments o’er,
North’s fell blast impetuous heaves,

But fiercer far when shield to shield
And arm to arm, the heroes strove;
When Carbier gain’d by fraud the field,
And Death bereft me of my love
Swift, as shaggy Morven’s77 Fingal’s kingdom in Macpherson’s The Works of Ossian. roe,
His steps outstript the mountain wind,
His right arm lifted on the foe,
Like thunder bolts, no pow’r could bind:
Yet Mercy, like the turtle mild,
Sat beaming in the eagle’s eye,
Which ever on the vanquish’d smil’d
And never bad the captive die.
By yon valley’s dark blue stream,
Where bearded thistles wave around,
And the red-wing’d meteors gleam,
In his narrow dwelling found:
There in sky-enwoven shrouds,
Chiefs and bards of other days,
Stooping from their fleecy clouds,
Sing my youthful warrior’s praise.
Virgin’s raise the song of woe—
Ossian bid thy harp complain—
Let the drops of sorrow flow,
Let them swell the briny main.
Oscar fair as morning’s ray,
In its brightest colours clad,
Breathless stretch’d upon the clay,
Lies full low in yonder glade.
